meta.title: Attachment Style Test | What's Your Love Style?
meta.description: Discover your attachment style through 10 relationship scenarios. Are you Secure, Anxious, Avoidant, or Fearful-Avoidant?

app.title: Attachment Style Test
app.subtitle: Discover your attachment style through 10 relationship scenarios
app.warning: This test is for entertainment purposes only and does not replace professional psychological assessment.

q1.text: Your partner hasn't texted back in 3 hours. What do you do?

options.a: They're probably busy. I'll just do my own thing.
options.b: Keep checking my phone anxiously and wonder if they're ignoring me.
options.c: Honestly don't really care. I don't like waiting for texts anyway.
options.d: Feel annoyed but refuse to text first ‚Äî I don't want to seem needy.

q2.text: Your partner says 'We need to talk.' What's your first reaction?

options.a: My heart drops ‚Äî are they breaking up with me?
options.b: I feel ready to have an open conversation about anything.
options.c: I want to avoid it but I guess I'll hear them out.
options.d: I get defensive and anxious at the same time.

q3.text: A close friend starts flirting with your partner. How do you react?

options.a: They're probably better than me anyway‚Ä¶ I knew I wasn't enough.
options.b: Whatever happens, happens. I can't control it.
options.c: I trust my partner and would talk to them honestly if needed.
options.d: I'm jealous but I don't say anything because I don't want to seem possessive.

q4.text: Your partner surprises you with a gift. Your reaction?

options.a: I'm happy and express my gratitude warmly.
options.b: I'm so moved I could cry, and I feel pressure to do something back.
options.c: It's a bit uncomfortable. They really didn't have to do that.
options.d: I'm pleased but also wonder if there's a hidden motive.

q5.text: After a big fight with your partner, what's your pattern?

options.a: I go silent and want space, but I'm terrified they'll leave.
options.b: I need distance to process my feelings alone.
options.c: I keep texting and calling to make up right away.
options.d: I wait until we've both cooled down, then talk it through calmly.

q6.text: You've just started seeing someone new. What are you like early on?

options.a: I constantly look for signs of how interested they are.
options.b: I fall hard and fast, but I'm scared they'll abandon me.
options.c: I take it slow, getting to know them at a comfortable pace.
options.d: If things get too close too fast, I pull back.

q7.text: Your partner says they need some alone time. What goes through your mind?

options.a: Great! I value my personal time too.
options.b: Even better ‚Äî I could use some breathing room.
options.c: Are they getting tired of me?
options.d: Part of me is relieved, but part of me worries they're pushing me away.

q8.text: Your partner is going through a tough time and leans on you emotionally. You...

options.b: Want to help but feel weighed down by the emotional burden.
options.c: Feel anxious but glad they need me.
options.d: Don't really know how to respond and feel uncomfortable.

q9.text: You find your partner's ex on social media. Your reaction?

options.a: I'm probably not as attractive as them anyway.
options.b: I deep-dive their profile and can't help comparing myself.
options.c: The past is the past. Doesn't bother me.
options.d: If I'm curious, I just ask my partner about it directly.

q10.text: How would you describe your ideal relationship in one sentence?

options.a: Respecting each other's space and living comfortably ‚Äî too much closeness feels suffocating.
options.b: Being constantly reassured and feeling loved every single moment.
options.c: Trusting each other deeply while respecting each person's individual life.
options.d: Wanting love but finding it hard to fully open up for fear of getting hurt.

secure.name: Secure
secure.desc: You have a secure attachment style. You feel comfortable in relationships, naturally trust your partner, and value both togetherness and personal space. When conflicts arise, you address them through honest communication rather than avoidance or escalation.
secure.idealPartner: You get along with all types, but another Secure partner creates the healthiest dynamic. You can also bring stability to Anxious or Avoidant partners.
secure.advice: You already have great relationship skills! Just be careful not to take on your partner's insecurity as your own fault. Your stability is a strength ‚Äî but don't forget to express your own needs too.

anxious.name: Anxious
anxious.desc: You have an anxious attachment style. You love deeply and are incredibly devoted, but carry a constant fear of abandonment. You're highly sensitive to your partner's mood shifts and crave reassurance and closeness.
anxious.idealPartner: A Secure partner is ideal ‚Äî someone who offers consistent reassurance and steady behavior. Be cautious with Avoidant types, as the push-pull dynamic can intensify your anxiety.
anxious.advice: Your partner's response time doesn't measure their love. When anxiety spikes, pause before reacting impulsively. Learning to love yourself first will make all your relationships healthier.

avoidant.name: Avoidant
avoidant.desc: You have an avoidant attachment style. You value independence and freedom, and too much closeness can make you uncomfortable. While you may struggle to express emotions openly, deep feelings exist beneath the surface. You need your own time and space.
avoidant.idealPartner: A Secure partner who gives you room without being clingy. Someone warm but not overwhelming can gradually help lower your walls. Anxious partners may trigger a chase-retreat cycle.
avoidant.advice: Getting close doesn't mean becoming weak. Try opening up little by little. It's okay to tell your partner you need space ‚Äî just also acknowledge their emotional needs. Balance is everything.

fearful.name: Fearful-Avoidant
fearful.desc: You have a fearful-avoidant (disorganized) attachment style. You crave intimacy but simultaneously fear it. You want to get close but pull back to protect yourself from being hurt. This inner conflict can make relationships complicated and emotionally turbulent.
fearful.idealPartner: A patient, Secure partner is ideal ‚Äî someone who understands your push-pull tendencies and stays steady through it all. Experiencing a safe relationship, even if it takes time, is crucial for growth.
fearful.advice: Your mixed feelings are a natural defense mechanism, but not every relationship ends in pain. Build trust gradually, starting small. Professional support can also be incredibly helpful. You absolutely deserve love.
